docs.lead_paragraph: During the long, tortured battle to win his seat as Minnesota's junior senator, Al Franken received an unusually large number of campaign contributions from fellow comedians and actors, compared with the corporate donations candidates traditionally rely upon. But Mr. Franken, a Democrat, has apparently quickly learned one of the first rules of incumbency: protect local industries.
docs.abstract: Minnesota Sen Al Franken sends letter to Sen Max Baucus saying that he opposes provision in health care proposal that would impose $4 billion in annual fees on makers of medical devices; Minnesota Sen Amy Klobuchar and Indiana Sens Richard G Lugar and Evan Bayh also sign letter; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers posted more than 1,250 comments on the Prescriptions blog Wednesday in response to coverage of Senator Max Baucus's introduction of his proposal to overhaul the health care system. Here is a sampling of the comments, in most cases condensed from longer postings.

docs.lead_paragraph: RISHER--Edward H.,M.D., 85 years. Died in Manhattan September 15, 2009 after a short illness, surrounded by his family, his loving wife, Lorrie, of 57 years, his children Mary Jo Foley (Stephen), Edward Jr. (Ariadna), Peter and Elise (Andrew Lavallee). In addition he leaves his grandchildren Nicholas and Benjamin Foley, Edward P. Risher, Lucia, Serafina and Delia Lavallee and his brothers Watson and Fred. Dr. Risher retired as Vice President of Employees' Health at New York Life Insurance Company. Memorial gathering will be held on Friday, September 18, 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISHER, EDWARD H.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the same moment on Wednesday that Senator Max Baucus was introducing his long-awaited blueprint for a health care overhaul, executives from nationally prominent medical groups were meeting nearby to discuss how to make more clinics and hospitals look like them. Among the attendees were executives from the Cleveland Clinic, Geisinger Health System, Bassett Healthcare and eight other health care systems in which doctors are paid a salary and patients are generally given care coordinated among a variety of specialists. Such systems have been cited by President Obama, Congressional leaders and policy experts as medical exemplars, providing high-quality care at reasonable cost.
docs.abstract: Executives from Cleveland Clinic, Geisinger Health System, Bassett Healthcare and eight other health care systems, cited by Pres Obama and policy experts as medical exemplars, meet to explore shared elements they can recommend to other clinics and hospitals; say secret of their success is that doctors are salaried and patients are given better coordinated care among specialists (S)
